questions.text: A patient who is a diagnosed case of HNPCC, which of the following is the most common repair associated with it? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mismatch repair

 

Explanation:

 

Mismatch Repair (MMR) defect leads to Hereditary Non-Polyposis Colorectal Cancer (HNPCC). This mechanism corrects errors that typically occur during DNA replication. Mutations in MMR genes result in microsatellite instability and contribute to the development of various cancers at an early age. In contrast, Homologous Repair (HR) defects are associated with other genetic disorders and cancers, including Bloom syndrome, Werner syndrome, breast cancer, and Ataxia-Telangiectasia like disorder.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nucleotide excision repair: Incorrect for this context as it deals with the repair of bulky helix-distorting lesions caused by UV radiation and chemicals, leading to diseases like Xeroderma pigmentosum.

 

Option C. Base excision repair: Incorrect as it fixes small non-helix-distorting bases caused by spontaneous or induced changes, leading to conditions like MUTYH-associated polyposis when defective.

 

Option D. Homologous recombinant repair: Incorrect for HNPCC. It repairs double-strand breaks or interstrand cross-links in DNA, not typically involved in the pathogenesis of HNPCC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref- Harper 31st e/pg. 370

questions.text: What is the diagnosis of the below image? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Horse Shoe Kidney

 

The CT image provided depicts a horseshoe kidney.

 

Horseshoe Kidney: In this condition, the two kidneys are joined together at their lower ends forming a U shape, often at the lower part of the abdomen across the midline. The image shows the kidneys joined across the midline, indicative of a horseshoe kidney.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Polycystic Kidney Disease: This condition is characterized by the presence of numerous cysts in the kidneys, which can cause the kidneys to enlarge and lose function over time. The image does not show multiple cysts characteristic of this disease.

 

Option C. Fused Ectopic Kidney: This refers to a kidney that is abnormally positioned and fused with the other kidney. It can appear similar to a horseshoe kidney but generally involves a displacement of one kidney.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Horseshoe kidney is a congenital disorder where the kidneys are connected at the lower ends and lie across the midline. It‚Äôs often asymptomatic but can be associated with complications like urinary tract infections or stones.

choices.text: Unconscious with Pulse present Breathing present
Conscious with Pulse present Breathing present

questions.text: This position is given in which patients? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Unconscious with Pulse present Breathing present

 

The position shown in the image is the recovery position. This position is used for unconscious patients who have a pulse and are breathing adequately. The purpose of placing a patient in the recovery position is to maintain a clear airway and prevent aspiration by allowing any fluids (like saliva or vomit) to drain from the mouth. This position also helps prevent the tongue from obstructing the airway.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pulse absent, Breathing present: If a patient is pulseless, they are in cardiac arrest and require immediate CPR, not placement in the recovery position.

 

Option B. Pulse absent, Breathing absent: In the absence of both pulse and breathing, the patient requires immediate CPR and advanced life support, not the recovery position.

 

Option D. Conscious with Pulse present, Breathing present: A conscious patient who is breathing and has a pulse would not need to be placed in the recovery position. They should be kept comfortable and monitored, but no special positioning is necessary unless they become unconscious.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The recovery position is used for unconscious patients who have a pulse and are breathing, to maintain airway patency and prevent aspiration.

questions.text: A patient who used to workout regularly at the gym, gradually developed pain in the hip which is aggravated while squatting. He gives history of regular steroid and creatine use over last six months. There is flattening of femoral head and subchondral cysts were seen on X-ray. What is the likely diagnosis?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) AVN of hip

 

AVASCULAR NECROSIS

 

  • Avascular necrosis (AVN) is the cellular death of components of bone due to impaired blood supply.
  • It affects anterolateral aspect of femoral head.
  • Etiopathogenesis: Idiopathic (most common) ‚Äì called as Chandeliers disease.
  • Causes:

 

 

  • Clinical Features:
    • Age 20-50 years with slight male preponderance (Young Male).
    • Bilateral in 50% of idiopathic cases, and 80% of steroid-induced cases.
    • Decreased range of motion especially internal rotation followed by abduction ‚Äì characteristic feature
    • A characteristic sign is a tendency for hip to twist into external rotation during passive flexion - ‚ÄòSectoral sign‚Äô ‚Äì with the hip extended, internal rotation is almost full but with hip flexed, it is grossly restricted ‚Äì due to a sector of femoral head being involved in AVN.
    • X-rays Sclerosed area shows area of necrosis; Crescent sign ‚Äì Crescentric defect in subchondral area.

 

 

  • MRI is the investigation of choice ‚Äì Double line sign is seen.
  • T1: Reduced intensity or irregular outline of head.
  • T2: High signal intensity called as double line sign.

 

 

  • Classification system:
    • University at Pennsylvania system:
      • Mild AVN: < 15% of Femoral head involved
      • Moderate AVN: 15-30% of Femoral head involved
      • Severe AVN: >30% of Femoral head involved
         
  • Treatment:
    • Early stages: protected weight-bearing.
    • Pre-collapse stage: Core decompression to decrease intraosseous pressure in femoral head (Normal Intraosseous pressure = 10-20 mm Hg; 3-4 times in AVN). Drill holes are made in femoral head. This procedure also opens the channels for vascular ingrowths and it is also supplemented with bone grafting (Vascular or nonvascular) or electrical stimulation or bone morphogenic proteins.

 

 

  • Muscle Pedicle graft: Quadratus femoris (Meyers graft)/Tensor fascia lata graft (Joshi‚Äôs graft) can be fixed in femoral head to augment vascularity.

 

 

  • Rotational osteotomy: To get the intact part of femoral head in acetabulum weight-bearing area (anterolateral aspect of femur head) this is an extensive procedure requiring vascular repair along with it.

 

 

  • Arthritis/Collapse of femoral head: Total hip replacement one of the very commonly done procedure as most patients present at stage of arthritis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. TB of hip. Initial focus is in the acetabulum. The majority of cases of hip TB presents as painful, restricted movements of the hip, and a limp. It is secondary to primary pathology in lungs, lymph nodes or any of the viscera. Disease usually starts during first three decades. Depending upon the extent of involvement, there can be deformity, shortening of the limb, swelling, pathological dislocations, and sinuses.

 

 

 

Wandering acetabulum

 

 

Stage of arthritis

 

Treatment involved Girdlestone excision arthroplasty/arthrodesis/THR.

 

 

Stage I and II are treated with ATT and traction. If required, joint debridement/synovectomy can be done. Stage III, IV and V are treated with ATT and joint replacement/arthrodesis/osteotomy/excision arthroplasty.

 

Option C. Fracture neck of femur. Femoral neck fractures are a specific type of intracapsular hip fracture. Femoral neck fractures are associated with low energy falls in the elderly. In younger patients, the cause is usually secondary to high-energy trauma such as a substantial height or motor vehicle accidents. Risk factors for femoral neck fractures include female gender, decreased mobility, and low bone density. Displaced fractures of the femoral neck put the blood supply at risk, usually tearing the ascending cervical branches. This may compromise the healing ability of the fracture, inevitably causing non-union or osteonecrosis. The patient will complain of pain with a decreased range of motion of the hip. In non-displaced fractures, there may be no deformity. However, displaced fractures may present with a shortened and externally rotated lower limb. MRI is more sensitive (100% sensitivity) and specific for diagnosis.

 

 

 

 

Garden‚Äôs classification

 

Treatment is done by closed reduction and internal fixation in age < 65 years. In age > 65 years, hemiarthroplasty is done if there is a pre-existing arthritis. If there is no pre-existing arthritis, total hip replacement is done.

 

Option D. Osteomalacia. Often referred to as "soft bone disease," is a metabolic bone disorder characterized by the inadequate mineralization of bone tissue. There is adult onset of bone softening and muscle weakness. This condition results from a deficiency in vitamin D, calcium, or phosphate, weakening and softening bones. Symptoms are non-specific and may include low back and thigh pain, proximal muscle weakness and wasting; Myalgia and arthralgia; Muscle spasms; waddling gait; Spinal, limb, or pelvic deformities; Aching bone pain aggravated by activity and weight-bearing; Increased falls; Hypocalcemic seizures or tetany. Triradiate pelvis, protrusion acetabular (acetabulum protrudes into pelvis due to bone softening. When bilateral, it is called as Otto Pelvis), pseudofracture are seen on x-ray. There is waddling gait due to muscular weakness.

 

 

A. Triradiate pelvis; B. Protrusio acetabuli

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Regular steroid is the major risk factor for development of avascular necrosis of the hip.
  • Flattening of femoral head on radiograph is also seen in the avascular necrosis of hip.

questions.text:
Identify the cause(s) that result in non-scarring alopecia from the following options: (INICET NOV 2023)

 

  1. Alopecia areata
  2. Telogen effluvium
  3. Androgenic alopecia
  4. Frontal fibrosing alopecia
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2 and 3

 

Explanation:

 

Androgenic alopecia, alopecia areata, and telogen effluvium (1, 2 and 3) are responsible for non-scarring alopecia. On the other hand, frontal fibrosing alopecia falls under the category of primary cicatricial (scarring) alopecia.

 

 

  1. Alopecia areata 
    • It is an autoimmune condition that causes patchy hair loss.
    • The hair follicles are not destroyed and can regrow hair if the underlying inflammation is treated, thus it is considered non-scarring.
  2. Telogen effluvium 
    • It is a form of temporary hair loss that typically occurs after stress, a shock, or a traumatic event.
    • The hair loss is diffuse and does not involve scarring of the scalp.
  3. Androgenic alopecia
    • It is also known as male or female pattern baldness, is characterized by a progressive thinning of the hair in a typical pattern.
    • The condition is non-scarring as the hair follicles gradually produce thinner and shorter hairs but are not destroyed.
  4. FRONTAL FIBROSING ALOPECIA
    • Type of Hair Loss: Scarring alopecia primarily affecting the frontal hairline and eyebrows.
    • Predominantly Affects: Postmenopausal women.
    • Symptoms: Progressive hairline recession, eyebrow loss, and sometimes body hair loss.
    • Clinical Features:
      • Frontal Hairline Recession: Gradual and symmetrical.
      • Eyebrow Thinning: Outer third of eyebrows commonly affected.

 

 

  • Perifollicular Erythema: Redness around hair follicles.
  • Potential Causes: Autoimmune or hormonal factors may play a role.
  • Treatment:
    • Medical Approaches: Topical or systemic corticosteroids, anti-inflammatory medications.
    • Cosmetic Solutions: Wigs, eyebrow makeup, tattoos.
  • Prognosis: Hair loss is often permanent; early intervention may slow progression.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Non-scarring alopecia, which allows for the possibility of hair regrowth, includes alopecia areata, telogen effluvium, and androgenic alopecia.
  • Frontal fibrosing alopecia is associated with scarring alopecia.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology 9th edition Page no 32.24, 32.39-40, 86.17, 89.6, 89.7, 89.14, 89.17, 89.20, 89.24, 89.25, 89.46

questions.text: Which deformity is shown in this image?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cubitus valgus

 

Explanation:

 

The image depicts an outward deviation of the forearm, which is known as cubitus valgus. In a normal carrying angle, there is a slight outward angulation at the elbow joint, which is more prominent in females. However, in cubitus valgus, the forearm deviates excessively outward, beyond the normal range. This condition is generally associated with ulnar nerve injury.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cubitus varus: Cubitus varus is the opposite of cubitus valgus, where the forearm deviates inward. This condition is also known as gunstock deformity and is often seen in supracondylar fractures of the humerus, where median nerve injury may also be present.

 

Option C. Gunstock deformity: Gunstock deformity is another term for cubitus varus, where the forearm deviates inward, resembling the shape of a gunstock. This is not the deformity shown in the given image.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cubitus valgus is an outward deviation of the forearm at the elbow joint, beyond the normal carrying angle, and is generally associated with ulnar nerve injury.

questions.text: What is the most common tumor of the lacrimal gland? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pleomorphic adenoma

 

Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common benign tumor of the lacrimal gland. This tumor is composed of a mix of ductal and myoepithelial cells, often presenting as a painless, progressive, firm mass typically located in the superolateral aspect of the orbit.

 

Details about Pleomorphic Adenoma:

 

  • Benign Nature: Despite its benign nature, pleomorphic adenoma can cause displacement of the eye and may alter vision due to its size and location.
  • Potential for Malignant Transformation: While it is primarily benign, there is a risk for malignant transformation into a carcinoma ex pleomorphic adenoma if not adequately treated or if left untreated for a long duration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adenoid cystic carcinoma: Although this is the most common malignant tumor of the lacrimal gland, it is not as frequently occurring as pleomorphic adenoma. Adenoid cystic carcinoma is known for its aggressive nature and poorer prognosis.

 

Option B. Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma: This type of tumor can involve the lacrimal gland but is generally less common than pleomorphic adenoma.

 

Option D. Mucoepidermoid carcinoma: This is another type of malignant tumor that can occur in the lacrimal gland, but it is also less common than pleomorphic adenoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common benign tumor of the lacrimal gland while adenoid cystic carcinoma is the most common malignant tumour of the lacrimal gland. Overall, benign tumours are more common, thus pleomorphic adenoma is the most common lacrimal gland tumour.

choices.text: Valvular heart disease due to rheumatic heart disease
Sudden cardiac death due to arrhythmia
Sudden cardiac death due to atherosclerosis

questions.text: An unfortunate incident occurred during a football match, where a young 20-year-old athlete tragically collapsed and was subsequently rushed to the hospital. Despite all efforts, the medical team could not save him, and he was pronounced deceased. The autopsy image provided gives us important information to investigate the cause of his untimely passing. What can be the most likely cause of death? (AIIMS MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sudden cardiac death due to arrhythmia

 

Given clinical scenario, image showing asymmetric septal hypertrophy and histo image shows extensive myocyte disarray suggests a diagnosis of Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and cause of sudden death in this scenario is Arrhythmia.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Valvular heart disease due to rheumatic heart disease: Valvular heart disease due to Rheumatic Heart Disease typically presents with valvular dysfunction (e.g., mitral stenosis) and is less common in causing sudden death in young athletes.

 

Option C. Death due to hypertrophied ventricle: While hypertrophied ventricles are a feature of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, the immediate cause of death is usually due to an arrhythmia, not merely the hypertrophy itself.

 

Option D. Sudden cardiac death due to atherosclerosis: Sudden cardiac death due to atherosclerosis is more common in older adults and less likely in a 20-year-old athlete.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sudden cardiac death due to arrhythmia is the most likely cause of death in young athlete with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, as indicated by the clinical scenario and autopsy findings.

 

HOCM is characterised by histological findings of myocyte disarray. (recent INICET ques)

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1061

choices.text: An HLA identical matched unrelated donor who is blood type O-
His HLA identical 50-year-old brother who is otherwise healthy and is blood type O+

questions.text: A 47-year-old man with a diagnosis of acute myeloid leukemia with a blood type O negative blood group presents to the transplant clinic to discuss proceeding with an allogeneic stem cell transplant. Which of the following would be an optimal donor? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. His HLA identical 50-year-old brother who is otherwise healthy and is blood type O+

 

  1. Due to the decreased risk of graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) with related transplants, related donor transplants are still favored over unrelated donor transplants.
  2. Rh incompatibility has no impact on the success of transplants (Rh antigen is only found on the surface of RBCs, not on the parenchymal cells of the graft).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Syngeneic transplantation (donation from identical twins) has been shown to increase the risk of relapse in cases of hematologic malignancies and is therefore not a source of donor that is advised.

 

Option B: Umbilical cord transplant is not usually recommended.

 

Option C: While ABO compatibility is vital when selecting a donor, this is merely a slight ABO discrepancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient with acute myeloid leukemia, the optimal donor choice would generally be an HLA identical sibling, despite any ABO blood type differences, due to the lower risk of complications and better overall survival outcomes. Blood type discrepancies, especially in Rh factor, are manageable in the context of stem cell transplants.

 

Reference - Harrison/Transplant/Chap 104

questions.text:
What is the grade of tympanic membrane retraction shown in the image?

(INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
‚úÖ Correct Answer: B. Grade 2

üì∏ Image Analysis:

The otoscopic image shows a retracted pars tensa where deeper middle ear structures like the long process of the incus and incudostapedial joint are visible. The lateral process of the malleus is prominently seen, and the tympanic membrane appears pulled medially, but it is not adherent to the promontory, and air is still visible in the middle ear. This presentation is typical of Grade 2 retraction.

üîç Explanation of Options:

Option A: Grade 1

In Grade 1 pars tensa retraction, there is only mild inward retraction. The cone of light is lost, the fibrous annulus appears more prominent, and the handle of the malleus becomes more medialized. Importantly, there is no contact with the ossicles, and ossicular landmarks like the incus are not visible. This does not match the findings seen in the image.

 

Option B: Grade 2

Grade 2 retraction is more severe than Grade 1, and the pars tensa is retracted to the extent that it touches the long process of the incus. Deeper structures like the incudostapedial joint, round window niche, and even the horizontal facial canal may be visible. The tympanic membrane still retains some mobility and is not adherent to the promontory. This fits the otoscopic image exactly, where ossicular structures are seen but no signs of complete adhesion are present.

 

Option C: Grade 3

In Grade 3 retraction, the tympanic membrane is severely retracted and becomes adherent to the promontory, forming what is called an atelectatic membrane. Although some air may still remain in the middle ear, the drum is essentially collapsed onto the medial wall. This condition is more advanced than what is seen in the current image.

 

Option D: Grade 4

This is the most severe stage where the entire tympanic membrane is stuck to the promontory, and there is complete loss of middle ear aeration. It often leads to adhesive otitis media, and ossicular erosion (such as necrosis of the incus) may occur. This is clearly not the case here, as ossicles are intact and the membrane is not fully adherent.

üß† Educational Objective:

Grade 2 pars tensa retraction is identified when the tympanic membrane retracts to touch the long process of the incus without adhering to the promontory, often revealing middle ear ossicles such as the incudostapedial joint.

questions.text: What is the causative agent for Hooch tragedy? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Methanol

 

Hooch tragedy is due to the consumption of adulterated liquor containing methanol. Methanol is a toxic form of alcohol that can cause severe health issues including blindness, metabolic acidosis, and death when ingested.

 

Hooch

 

  • Definition: It is ethyl alcohol illegally adulterated with other harmful substances
  • Methanol as adulterant: A common harmful adulterant in hooch is methanol
  • Sources of methanol in Ethanol: There are two ways by which methanol gets added in the ethanol:
    • Added deliberately to ethanol due to its low price or
    • Produced during ethanol production (fermentation): Methanol can get naturally produced along with ethanol during the production of ethanol by fermentation. Usually it gets removed by distillation, but in local and illegal production, the distillation is of poor quality.
  • Hooch tragedy in India: In India, local alcohol is made illegally from cane sugar, is sold very cheap for a plastic pouch or glass. In Bihar and some other states, it has resulted in deaths of multiple people at different times

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phosphorus: Phosphorus poisoning usually occurs due to ingestion of substances like rodenticides or fireworks and is not associated with hooch tragedies.

 

Option B. Mercury: Mercury poisoning occurs from exposure to mercury or its compounds and is not linked to hooch tragedies.

 

Option C. Ethanol: Ethanol is the intended product of alcoholic beverages. It is not the cause of hooch tragedies unless it is adulterated with toxic substances like methanol.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hooch tragedies occur due to the consumption of illicitly brewed liquor contaminated with methanol, a toxic form of alcohol that can cause severe health effects including death.

questions.text: Which of the following is found only in cytoplasm: (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Glycolysis

 

Explanation

 

Correct Answer. Glycolysis, the process of breaking down glucose to pyruvate, occurs exclusively in the cytoplasm. It is the first major pathway of glucose catabolism and occurs in both aerobic and anaerobic conditions. Glycolysis is unique among these options as being the only pathway confined to the cytoplasm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. TCA Cycle: The Tricarboxylic Acid (TCA) cycle, also known as the Krebs cycle, takes place in the mitochondria, not in the cytoplasm. It is a key metabolic pathway for the oxidation of carbohydrates, fats, and proteins, leading to the production of ATP.

 

Option B. Beta-oxidation of Fatty Acids: Beta-oxidation, the process of breaking down fatty acids to produce acetyl-CoA, occurs in the mitochondria. In some cells, like liver cells, it can also occur in peroxisomes, but it does not take place in the cytoplasm.

 

Option D. Gluconeogenesis: Although some steps of gluconeogenesis occur in the cytoplasm, it is not exclusive to this compartment. This metabolic pathway, which generates glucose from non-carbohydrate substrates, involves steps that occur in both the cytoplasm and mitochondria (and to a lesser extent, the endoplasmic reticulum).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Generally, all Anabolic Pathways occur in Cytoplasm and all Catabolic Pathways occur in Mitochondria
  • Exception: Two catabolic pathways also occur in cytoplasm.
    1. Glycolysis
    2. Glycogenolysis

 

 However, three processes occur both in cytoplasm and mitochondria.

 

  1. Heme Synthesis 
  2. Urea cycle
  3. Gluconeogenesis

 

Ref: Harper‚Äôs Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 139

questions.text: In an isolated mitochondria, in a medium containing Succinate, Fumarate, ADP and Pi, ATPs were produced. Later a compound was added, and oxidative phosphorylation was decreased. What‚Äôs that compound? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Oligomycin

 

  • Oligomycin is an antibiotic that inhibits ATP synthase, a key enzyme complex in oxidative phosphorylation. It blocks the flow of protons (H+) through ATP synthase, preventing ATP synthesis. As a result, adding oligomycin would indeed decrease oxidative phosphorylation, leading to a reduction in ATP production.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 2,4-dinitrophenol (DNP): 2,4-dinitrophenol is a chemical uncoupler of oxidative phosphorylation. It disrupts the proton gradient across the inner mitochondrial membrane, making it leaky to protons. This uncoupling reduces the efficiency of ATP production but doesn't directly inhibit oxidative phosphorylation.

 

Option C. Antimycin: Antimycin is an inhibitor of complex III (cytochrome bc1 complex) in the electron transport chain. It blocks the transfer of electrons from ubiquinone to cytochrome c, disrupting the electron flow in the chain.

 

Option D. Rotenone: Rotenone is an inhibitor of complex I in the electron transport chain. It prevents the transfer of electrons from NADH to ubiquinone, disrupting electron flow.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oligomycin specifically targets ATP synthase and inhibits ATP synthesis in oxidative phosphorylation. Therefore, the compound that was added to the isolated mitochondria, leading to a decrease in oxidative phosphorylation

 

Ref-Harper 31st e/pg. 123

choices.text: Estimated fetal weight < 3rd percentile
Absent or reversal of diastolic flow in umbilical artery

questions.text: All are criteria of IUGR except? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Uterine A PI < 95%

 

Intrauterine Growth Restriction (IUGR) is a condition where a fetus is smaller than expected for the number of weeks of pregnancy. It can result from various factors, including placental insufficiency, maternal health issues, or genetic conditions. Several criteria are commonly used to diagnose IUGR:

 

  • Abdominal circumference < 3rd percentile: This is a common marker used in the assessment of IUGR. A small abdominal circumference indicates that the fetus might not be growing adequately.
  • Estimated fetal weight < 3rd percentile: Like abdominal circumference, if the estimated fetal weight is below the 3rd percentile, it is a strong indicator of IUGR.
  • Absent or reversal of diastolic flow in the umbilical artery: This is a critical finding on Doppler ultrasound that indicates severe placental insufficiency. It is associated with increased risk of adverse perinatal outcomes.

 

However, the option "Uterine A PI < 95%" refers to the uterine artery pulsatility index (PI), which is a measure of the resistance in the uterine artery. In cases of IUGR, resistance is typically high, leading to a high PI, not low. Therefore, a PI < 95% (indicating low resistance) would not be consistent with IUGR. This is why this option is incorrect.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Abdominal circumference < 3rd percentile: This is a valid criterion used in the assessment of IUGR.

 

Option B. Estimated fetal weight < 3rd percentile: This criterion is also used in the diagnosis of IUGR.

 

Option C. Absent or reversal of diastolic flow in the umbilical artery: This is a critical sign of severe IUGR and is often associated with poor perinatal outcomes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The uterine artery pulsatility index (PI) is typically high in cases of IUGR due to increased resistance. A low PI (< 95%) would not indicate IUGR, making it the incorrect option in this contex

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient comes with complaints of progressive weakness as the day progresses. He is found to have antibodies against nicotinic acetylcholine receptors. Which is the most common ocular finding in this disease? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Ptosis

 

The clinical scenario is suggestive of a diagnosis of Myasthenia gravis.

 

  • Myasthenia gravis (MG) is a neuromuscular disorder that affects the cranial muscles, including the lids and extraocular muscles (EOMs).
  • Ptosis and diplopia are common initial complaints in MG.
  • Ptosis is the most common ocular feature in MG.
  • The cranial muscles are typically involved early in the course of MG.
  • If weakness remains restricted to the EOMs for 3 years, it is likely that it will not become generalized.
  • Patients who only experience weakness in the EOMs for 3 years are said to have ocular MG.

 

Tensilon test:

 

In Myasthenia, there is improvement of ptosis with IV inj. of Edrophonium (Tensilon).

 

 

Lagophthalmos and Exophthalmos are signs of Thyroid Eye Disease.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Diplopia: Common in MG but less frequent than ptosis.

 

Option B. Lagophthalmos: Inability to close the eyelids completely, typically associated with thyroid eye disease or facial nerve palsy, not common in MG.

 

Option C. Exophthalmos: Protrusion of the eyeball, commonly seen in thyroid eye disease, not MG.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ptosis (drooping of the upper eyelid) is the most common ocular finding in Myasthenia Gravis, a neuromuscular disorder characterized by antibodies against nicotinic acetylcholine receptors.

questions.text: A child as shown below presented to the ENT department with the following finding. She gives complaint of recurrent bony fractures along with reduced hearing. On further investigation, Tympanometry showed the following finding. What would you name this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Van der Hoeve syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

The child presents with recurrent bony fractures and reduced hearing, which are indicative of osteogenesis imperfecta (imperfectly developed bones).

 

The tympanometry shows an AS type of curve, suggesting otosclerosis.

 

Additionally, the child has a blue sclera, which is a characteristic feature of osteogenesis imperfecta.

 

This combination of symptoms ‚Äî osteogenesis imperfecta, blue sclera, and otosclerosis ‚Äî forms a triad known as Van der Hoeve syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Waardenburg syndrome: Waardenburg syndrome is characterized by congenital sensorineural hearing loss and pigmentary abnormalities such as a white forelock of hair (piebaldism).

 

 

Option C. Usher's syndrome: Usher's syndrome is associated with retinitis pigmentosa and congenital sensorineural hearing loss.

 

                Retinitis pigmentosa

 

Option D. Pendred syndrome: Pendred syndrome includes congenital sensorineural hearing loss and goiter.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Van der Hoeve syndrome is characterized by the triad of osteogenesis imperfecta, blue sclera, and otosclerosis.

questions.text: What is the fear of heights known as?(NEET PG  2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Acrophobia

 

This is the fear of heights.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acarophobia: This is the fear of itching or of the insects that cause itching.

 

Option B. Algophobia: This is the fear of pain.

 

Option C. Agoraphobia: This is the fear of open spaces or of being in crowded, public places like markets, or the fear of leaving a safe place, often associated with panic attacks.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Acrophobia refers to the fear of heights.

 

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock‚Äôs Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 403.

questions.text: Confusion assessment test is used in:(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Delirium

 

The Confusion Assessment Method (often referred to as CAM) is a diagnostic tool specifically designed to identify delirium.

 

CAM is used primarily for the detection of delirium, especially in hospitalized or elderly patients. It evaluates features like acute onset and fluctuating course, inattention, disorganized thinking, and altered level of consciousness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dementia: While CAM can help differentiate delirium from dementia, it is not specifically designed for the diagnosis of dementia.

 

Option C. Schizophrenia: CAM is not used in the diagnosis or assessment of schizophrenia.

 

Option D. Depression: CAM is not used in the diagnosis or assessment of depression.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The Confusion Assessment Method (CAM) is a tool specifically developed to detect delirium. Bedside examinations such as mini mental status examination (MMSE) are used to provide a measure of cognitive impairment.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock‚Äôs Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 701.

questions.text: A patient with dermatitis herpetiformis presented with chronic diarrhea. What is the likely cause of diarrhea? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Celiac disease

 

Dermatitis herpetiformis is a chronic skin condition characterized by intensely itchy and blistering skin lesions. It is strongly associated with celiac disease, an autoimmune disorder triggered by the ingestion of gluten. In celiac disease, exposure to gluten leads to an immune response that damages the lining of the small intestine, resulting in malabsorption and chronic diarrhea.

 

Key points:

 

  • Dermatitis herpetiformis: This condition involves IgA deposits in the tips of the dermal papillae, as seen on skin biopsy. It is a specific marker for celiac disease.
  • Celiac disease: Caused by gluten hypersensitivity, it leads to intestinal inflammation, villous atrophy, and malabsorption, which in turn causes chronic diarrhea.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Ulcerative colitis: This is an inflammatory bowel disease affecting the colon and rectum, leading to symptoms like diarrhea and abdominal pain. It is not associated with dermatitis herpetiformis.

 

Option B. Whipple’s disease: This rare bacterial infection affects multiple systems, including the intestines, causing malabsorption and diarrhea. It does not have a connection with dermatitis herpetiformis.

 

Option D. Crohn’s disease: Another type of inflammatory bowel disease that can affect any part of the gastrointestinal tract, causing chronic diarrhea and abdominal pain. It is not related to dermatitis herpetiformis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dermatitis herpetiformis is a skin manifestation of celiac disease, and the presence of chronic diarrhea in such a patient is indicative of celiac disease due to gluten hypersensitivity.

questions.text: Match the postmortem findings and their time of appearance:(INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. A-4, B-1, C-2, D-3

 

Postmortem changes occur in a sequential manner and can be used to estimate the time since death. The matching of these findings with their respective times of appearance is as follows:

 

  1. Adipocere formation
    • Time of appearance: 8-10 days
    • Explanation: Adipocere, also known as grave wax, is a postmortem change that occurs when body fat undergoes a transformation into a waxy substance in a moist environment. This process typically begins around 8-10 days after death.
  2. Relaxation of urethral sphincter
    • Time of appearance: 24 hrs
    • Explanation: After death, muscle relaxation, including the relaxation of the urethral sphincter, occurs due to the cessation of neural activity and muscle tone, typically around 24 hours postmortem.
  3. Marbling of veins
    • Time of appearance: 2-3 days
    • Explanation: Marbling refers to the appearance of greenish-black discoloration along the veins due to the breakdown of hemoglobin and the production of hydrogen sulphide gas by bacteria. This occurs approximately 2-3 days after death.
  4. Liquefaction of tissues
    • Time of appearance: 4-5 days
    • Explanation: Tissue liquefaction is a stage of decomposition where tissues start to break down into a liquid form. This process typically begins around 4-5 days postmortem.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amongst postmortem findings:

 

  • Adipocere formation is by 8-10 days
  • Relaxation of urethral sphincter is by 24 hrs.
  • Marbling of veins is by 2-3 days
  • Liquefaction of tissues is by 4-5 days

questions.text: A contact lens user presents with the following clinical picture. He has had watering, redness, and foreign body sensation in the eye for the past 2 months. What is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Giant papillary conjunctivitis

 

  • The clinical history of watering, redness, and foreign body sensation in a contact lens user, along with the image showing giant papillae in the conjunctiva, suggests a probable diagnosis of giant papillary conjunctivitis.
  • Giant papillary conjunctivitis is the inflammation of conjunctiva with formation of very large sized papillae.
  • Etiology - It is a localized allergic response to a physically rough or deposited surface (contact lens, prosthesis, left out nylon sutures).
  • Symptoms - Itching, stringy discharge and reduced wearing time of contact lens or prosthetic shell.
  • Signs - Papillary hypertrophy (1 mm in diameter) of the upper tarsal conjunctiva with hyperemia. Focal apical ulceration and whitish scarring may develop on larger papillae. Papillae are reddish, flat-topped, raised areas that give a red and velvety appearance to the tarsal conjunctiva.
  • Treatment:
    1. The offending cause should be removed. After discontinuation of contact lens or artificial eye or removal of nylon sutures, the papillae resolve over a period of one month.
    2. Disodium cromoglycate is known to relieve the symptoms and enhance the rate of resolution.
    3. Steroids are not of much use in this condition.

 

Other Options:

                                        

Option A. In acute trachoma, sago-like follicles are characteristically seen. It is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis. The SAFE strategy is used in the management of trachoma.

 

The image below shows sago-like follicles in trachoma.

 

 

Option B. It is an acute catarrhal conjunctivitis associated with marked follicular hyperplasia especially of the lower fornix and lower palpebral conjunctiva. Follicles are greyish-white raised areas on fornices and palpebral conjunctiva. These are formed due to the localized aggregations of lymphocytes in the sub-epithelial adenoid layer. It is most commonly caused by herpes and adenoviruses.

 

The image shows follicles.

 

 

Option D. Spring catarrh is considered a hypersensitivity reaction to some exogenous allergen, such as grass pollens. It is more common during summer. Cobblestone appearance (which is a papillary reaction in the palpebral conjunctiva), ropy discharge, and Maxwell-Lyon sign are present. Horner-Trantas spots that are discrete, whitish, raised dots along the limbus can also be seen.

 

The image below shows Horner-Trantas spots.

 

 

Pseudogerontoxon - Pseudogerontoxon is a lesion that resembles a small segment of arcus senilis or gerontoxon and is seen in many individuals with limbal vernal or atopic keratoconjunctivitis. It is an important clinical finding because pseudogerontoxon is often times the only clinical evidence of previous allergic eye disease.

 

 

Shield Ulcer- Localized oval or pentagonal lesion in upper cornea.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Giant papillary conjunctivitis is characterized by the presence of large papillae on the upper tarsal conjunctiva, often due to a localized allergic response to contact lenses or other foreign bodies.

choices.text: It occurs due to the persistence of prochordal plate
It occurs due to the defective migration of primordial cells to the genital ridge
It contains skin, cartilage and bone
It is a benign tumor of coccyx

questions.text: Which of the following statements is wrong about the clinical pediatric case as shown in the image? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It occurs due to the persistence of prochordal plate

 

 

 

The image shows a sacrococcygeal teratoma, which is a tumor located at the base of the coccyx in newborns. It is the most common tumor in neonates, and its origin and characteristics are well understood.

 

  • Persistence of Primitive Streak: Sacrococcygeal teratomas arise from the remnants of the primitive streak, not from the prochordal plate. The primitive streak is a structure in early embryonic development that usually regresses, but if remnants persist, they can lead to the formation of these tumors.
  • Defective Migration of Primordial Cells: This statement is correct as primordial germ cells that fail to migrate properly to the genital ridge can contribute to the formation of teratomas.
  • Contains Skin, Cartilage, and Bone: Teratomas are composed of tissues derived from all three germ layers: ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm. Therefore, they can contain a variety of tissue types including skin, cartilage, and bone.
  • Benign Tumor of Coccyx: Sacrococcygeal teratomas are generally benign, although they can sometimes be malignant.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Defective migration of primordial cells to the genital ridge: This statement is correct. Defective migration can result in teratomas.

 

Option C. Contains skin, cartilage, and bone: This statement is correct as teratomas can contain these tissues.

 

Option D. Benign tumor of coccyx: This statement is correct as sacrococcygeal teratomas are often benign.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sacrococcygeal teratomas arise from the remnants of the primitive streak and can contain various tissues including skin, cartilage, and bone. They are typically benign tumors located at the base of the coccyx.

questions.text: A woman in her early 40s comes to your clinic, displaying a winding, pronounced swelling that covers the left region of her scalp and face, as visible in the provided image. Upon physical examination, you notice the swelling exhibits a rhythmic pulsation. When listening to the area with a stethoscope, a sound indicative of turbulent blood flow - a bruit - is heard. What could be the most probable diagnosis in this case? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cirsoid Aneurysm

 

The above image is suggestive of a Cirsoid aneurysm.

 

  1. Definition: Cirsoid aneurysms, also known as arteriovenous fistulas or arteriovenous malformations, are abnormal connections between arteries and veins without the usual intervening capillaries.
  2. Common locations: They most commonly occur in the scalp and face, although they can occur in other locations in the body.
  3. Causes: They can be congenital (present at birth) or acquired, often as a result of trauma.
  4. Symptoms: Cirsoid aneurysms often present as a pulsatile mass, sometimes accompanied by a bruit (a sound heard over an artery due to turbulent blood flow). They can cause cosmetic concerns, headaches, and in severe cases, bleeding.
  5. Diagnosis: They can be diagnosed through physical examination and imaging studies such as ultrasound, CT, or MRI. Angiography can provide a detailed view of the blood vessels.
  6. Treatment: Treatment options include surgical excision, embolization (blocking off the abnormal vessels), or a combination of both. The choice of treatment depends on the size and location of the aneurysm, and the patient's overall health status.
  7. Complications: If left untreated, they can result in complications such as bleeding, ulceration, and, rarely, heart failure due to the increased blood flow through the malformation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Neurofibromatosis:

 

  • Location: Neurofibromatosis (NF) is a genetic disorder that can affect multiple systems, including the skin and nerves.
  • Symptoms: Symptoms vary but can include skin tumors (neurofibromas), caf√©-au-lait spots, and neurological problems

 

 

Option B. Liposarcoma:

 

  • Location: Liposarcoma is a type of soft tissue sarcoma that typically arises in fat cells in various parts of the body, including the limbs and abdomen.
  • Causes: The exact cause is often unknown, but some genetic factors may contribute. Symptoms: Symptoms may include a painless lump, swelling, or pain in the affected area.

 

Option D. Varicocele:

 

  • Location: Varicoceles are dilated veins in the scrotum, specifically in the spermatic cord. Causes: Varicoceles often develop due to faulty valves in the testicular veins, which allow blood to pool in the scrotum.
  • Symptoms: They may cause a dull ache or discomfort in the scrotum, especially after prolonged standing.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cirsoid aneurysms are arteriovenous malformations commonly found in the scalp and face, presenting as pulsatile masses with associated bruits. Proper diagnosis and treatment are essential to prevent complications such as bleeding and cosmetic concerns.

questions.text: After successful delivery of the baby, the obstetrician witnesses that the episiotomy performed has extended backwards beyond the perineal body. Which among the following structures is likely to be injured in this case? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) External anal sphincter

 

Explanation

 

  • Obstetrical Anal Sphincter Injuries (OASIS) include third and fourth-degree lacerations.
  • Third-degree lacerations involve the external anal sphincter:
    • 3A: Less than 50% of the external anal sphincter torn.
    • 3B: More than 50% of the external anal sphincter torn.
    • 3C: Both the external and internal anal sphincter torn.
  • Fourth-degree lacerations extend to the rectal mucosa.
  • In the scenario mentioned, the episiotomy has extended backward beyond the perineal body, likely damaging the anal sphincter and potentially the anal mucosa.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: Ischiocavernosus: This muscle is located more laterally and is less likely to be involved in a backward extension of the episiotomy.

 

Option C: Bulbospongiosus: This muscle is located in the perineal body and is usually affected by a standard episiotomy, but not specifically by a backward extension beyond the perineal body.

 

Option D: Urethral sphincter: This sphincter is located anteriorly and is not involved in a backward extension of the episiotomy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases where an episiotomy extends backward beyond the perineal body, the external anal sphincter is the structure most likely to be injured.

 

Ref: Page no 1307, Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition

questions.text: Identify the condition: (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Oculomotor nerve palsy

 

The given image suggests a diagnosis of oculomotor nerve palsy because of the following features:

 

  • Left eye is deviating downwards and outwards.
  • Left eyelid is showing ptosis.
  • Left eye is unable to move upwards, downwards, or inwards towards the nose, indicating a lack of adduction, elevation, and depression.

 

Signs observed in a patient with oculomotor nerve palsy include:

 

  • Profound ptosis due to the weakness of the levator muscle
  • Abduction and depression in the primary position (‚Äúdown and out‚Äù) due to unopposed action of the lateral rectus and superior oblique muscles.
  • Intorsion of the eye at rest due to the intact superior oblique.
  • Normal abduction due to the intact lateral rectus.

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Medial rectus palsy: Incorrect because. Medial rectus palsy specifically affects the ability of the eye to adduct (move inward toward the nose). If only the medial rectus were paretic, you would primarily observe limitation in horizontal inward movement of the affected eye without the associated ptosis, "down and out" positioning, or pupil involvement seen in the provided images. These broader symptoms indicate involvement of multiple muscles, which is characteristic of oculomotor nerve palsy, not isolated medial rectus palsy.

 

Option B. Trochlear nerve palsy: Incorrect because. Trochlear nerve (cranial nerve IV) palsy affects the superior oblique muscle, which primarily results in problems with eye rotation and vertical gaze, especially when looking downward and inward. Patients often present with vertical diplopia (double vision), head tilt away from the side of the lesion to compensate for the misalignment, and no ptosis or pupillary involvement. The symptoms and the eye movement limitations shown in the images do not match those typically associated with trochlear nerve palsy.

 

Option C. Abducens nerve palsy: Incorrect because. Abducens nerve (cranial nerve VI) palsy results in failure of the lateral rectus muscle, leading to an inability to abduct the eye (move outward). Patients with this condition will have the affected eye positioned inward (medially) due to unopposed action of the medial rectus. This condition would not cause the ptosis or the "down and out" appearance nor the wide range of motion impairments displayed in the images, such as the inability to move the eye upward or downward.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oculomotor nerve palsy significantly affects eye movement and eyelid function due to its role in innervating most of the extraocular muscles as well as lifting the eyelid. Diagnosis often involves a comprehensive evaluation of eye movement patterns, eyelid function, and pupil response, along with investigations to determine underlying causes. Treatment focuses on addressing the root cause and managing symptoms to protect eye function and quality of life.

questions.text: Which of the following drug is the most common used in day care surgery/TIVA?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Propofol

 

Propofol is the most commonly used drug in daycare surgery and total intravenous anesthesia (TIVA). Daycare surgeries are short-duration procedures where the patient is admitted, operated on, and discharged on the same day.

 

TIVA refers to anesthesia that is both induced and maintained using intravenous agents, without the use of inhalational anesthetics. Propofol is ideal for these scenarios because it has a rapid onset and allows for a quick, clear-headed recovery after the procedure. It is known for inducing a state of unconsciousness that is described as "dreamless sleep," meaning that patients do not experience vivid dreams or nightmares during anesthesia. Furthermore, propofol has beneficial postoperative effects, including anti-emetic (preventing nausea and vomiting) and anti-pruritic (preventing itching) properties, which enhance patient comfort and satisfaction post-surgery. The drug is quickly metabolized, allowing patients to wake up promptly and with minimal residual effects, making it highly suitable for short-duration surgeries.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sodium thiopentone: While sodium thiopentone is a rapid-onset barbiturate that was once commonly used for induction of anesthesia, it is not preferred for TIVA or daycare surgeries because it has a longer half-life and can lead to a prolonged recovery period. Additionally, it lacks the anti-emetic and anti-pruritic properties of propofol.

 

Option C. Halothane: Halothane is an inhalational anesthetic agent and not used in TIVA, which relies solely on intravenous drugs. It is also associated with several side effects, including hepatotoxicity (liver toxicity), which makes it less ideal for daycare surgeries where quick recovery and minimal side effects are desirable.

 

Option D. Ketamine: Ketamine is an intravenous anesthetic that provides both anesthesia and analgesia. It is used in some cases for TIVA, especially in patients with cardiovascular instability because it does not depress the cardiovascular system. However, it can cause vivid dreams or hallucinations during recovery, making it less suitable for daycare surgeries where a smooth and clear-headed recovery is preferred.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Propofol is the drug of choice for day care surgeries and total intravenous anesthesia (TIVA) due to its rapid onset, quick metabolism, and minimal postoperative side effects, including anti-emetic and anti-pruritic effects

questions.text: A 65-year-old guy arrives with tense, itchy bullae over his limbs. The roof of the bullae collapsed after a few days. What is the most likely diagnosis shown in the clinical image below? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bullous pemphigoid

 

The given clinical scenario is highly suggestive of bullous pemphigoid.

 

  • Elderly aged people are usually affected.
  • It presents as tense itchy bulla, which do not rupture easily, which can have an erythematous base (urticarial wheals) & the roof of the bullae collapses after a few days forming settled bulla, autoantibodies (IgG) against BP180 (BPAG2) and BP 230 (BPAG1) antigens on hemidesmosomes are seen in these patients.
  • It is a subepidermal blistering disorder, so acantholysis will not be seen.
  • Histopathology: subepidermal bullae with eosinophils
  • DIF: deposition of IgG antibodies at the dermo-epidermal junction in a linear pattern.
  • It is mainly treated with Topical corticosteroids.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pemphigus vulgaris: This is another autoimmune blistering disorder. However, the blisters in pemphigus vulgaris are flaccid and easily ruptured as shown in the image below, as opposed to the tense bullae seen in bullous pemphigoid. Additionally, the oral mucosa is frequently involved in pemphigus vulgaris.

 

 

Option C. Dermatitis herpetiformis: This condition is associated with gluten-sensitive enteropathy (celiac disease) and presents with itchy papules, vesicles, and bullae. However, the distribution is typically on extensor surfaces like elbows and knees as shown in the image below, and the appearance differs from what is shown in the image in the MCQ.

 

 

Option D. Linear IgA dermatosis: This is a rare autoimmune blistering disorder. The blisters are typically in a "string of pearls" or annular arrangement as shown in the image below.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

"Bullous Pemphigoid is a subepidermal blistering disorder predominantly affecting the elderly, characterized by tense itchy bullae, autoantibodies against BP180 and BP230, and eosinophilic involvement."

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 50, Page no. 50.4-50.37.

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in the vertex presentation with complete flexion attitude of head? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Suboccipito-bregmatic diameter

 

Explanation:

 

Suboccipito-bregmatic diameter (9.5 cm) is seen in vertex presentation with a complete flexion attitude of the head.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Suboccipito-frontal diameter:

 

  • This diameter measures about 10.5 cm and is seen when the head is only partially flexed.
  • It is not the smallest diameter and is not optimal for vertex presentations with complete flexion.

 

Option C. Occipito-frontal diameter:

 

  • This diameter measures approximately 11.5 cm and is seen in cases where the head is in a neutral position, neither fully flexed nor extended.
  • It is larger and more difficult for the passage of the fetal head through the birth canal.

 

Option D. Occipito-posterior position:

 

  • This is not a diameter but a fetal position where the back of the fetal head is directed towards the mother's back.
  • This position often leads to a more difficult labor and is associated with different presenting diameters, depending on the degree of head flexion or extension.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The suboccipito-bregmatic diameter (9.5 cm) is seen in vertex presentation with complete flexion of the fetal head, facilitating easier passage through the birth canal.

 

Ref: Page no   92 Textbook of obstetrics by JB Sharma

questions.text: A patient presents with foul-smell from nose and nasal obstruction. The image of the finding is given below. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Atrophic rhinitis

 

Based on the image showing a significant amount of crusting and given the symptom of foul smell, the most likely diagnosis is Option A, Atrophic rhinitis.

 

Atrophic rhinitis is characterized by a thickening and drying out of the mucous membrane in the nose, leading to crusting, a widened nasal cavity, and a foul smell. The image showing thick, greenish crusts is consistent with this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rhinitis sicca: Is associated with dryness of the nasal mucosa but without the severe crusting or foul smell typically seen in atrophic rhinitis. It usually does not present with the extent of crusting or debris depicted in the image.

 

Option C. Rhinosporidiosis: Is a chronic infection caused by the organism Rhinosporidium seeberi. It typically presents with polyp-like masses in the nasal passage, which may be friable and bleed easily. The image does not clearly show polyp-like structures, which would be more indicative of this condition.

 

Option D. Allergic rhinitis: Is an allergic response causing symptoms like sneezing, itching, and a runny nose, often related to seasonal allergens. It does not cause the thick crusting or the foul smell evident in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The clinical presentation of Atrophic Rhinitis is crucial, especially the distinctive symptoms of nasal obstruction and a foul-smelling discharge, along with visible crusting as seen in the provided image. This helps differentiate it from other forms of rhinitis, which do not present with such severe crusting or malodour.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of nausea, diarrhea, and vomiting. Upon further investigation, arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis reveals the following: pH: 7.55, PCO2: 50 mmHg, HCO3-: 44 mmol/L. Given these findings, which of the following conditions is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Metabolic Alkalosis

 

The ABG analysis reveals a pH of 7.55, indicating alkalosis (normal pH range: 7.35-7.45). The elevated bicarbonate (HCO3-) level of 44 mmol/L (normal range: 22-28 mmol/L) points towards a metabolic origin for the alkalosis. In metabolic alkalosis, the kidneys retain bicarbonate, leading to an increase in serum bicarbonate levels.

 

Additionally, the elevated PCO2 (partial pressure of carbon dioxide) of 50 mmHg (normal range: 35-45 mmHg) indicates a compensatory respiratory response. In metabolic alkalosis, the body attempts to compensate by hypoventilation, which increases PCO2 to counteract the rise in pH.

 

  • pH 7.55: Indicates alkalosis.
  • PCO2 50 mmHg: Elevated, indicating respiratory compensation.
  • HCO3- 44 mmol/L: Elevated, indicating a metabolic cause.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Respiratory Acidosis: This condition is characterized by a low pH and high PCO2 due to impaired ventilation, resulting in CO2 retention. The pH would be acidic, not alkalotic.

 

Option B. Respiratory Alkalosis: This condition involves a high pH and low PCO2 due to hyperventilation. However, in this case, PCO2 is elevated, not decreased.

 

Option C. Metabolic Acidosis: This condition involves a low pH and low bicarbonate levels due to an accumulation of acid or loss of bicarbonate. The pH here is alkalotic, not acidic.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Metabolic alkalosis is characterized by an elevated pH and bicarbonate level, with respiratory compensation leading to increased PCO2.

questions.text: Which stain is commonly used to differentiate the infarcted portion from the normal portion of the heart in a deceased patient who died due to myocardial infarction (MI)? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Triphenyl Tetrazolium chloride

 

 

Triphenyl tetrazolium chloride stain used to differentiate the infarct portion to the normal portion of heart following image is showing triphenyl tetrazolium chloride stain where BRICK RED colour is showing normal tissue and PALE color is showing MI.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Methylene blue: This stain is commonly used for highlighting various cell structures but is not specific for differentiating infarcted myocardial tissue.

 

Option C. Congo red: This stain is used to identify amyloid deposits in tissues, not for myocardial infarction.

 

Option D. Oil red O: This is a fat-soluble dye used to stain lipids in tissues, not specific for myocardial infarction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Triphenyl tetrazolium chloride (TTC) stain is used to differentiate infarcted myocardial tissue from normal tissue, with normal tissue appearing brick red and infarcted tissue appearing pale.

questions.text: Reinke crystals are seen in which of the following gonadal tumours: (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Leydig cell tumor

 

  • Reinke crystals are a specific and distinguishing feature of Leydig cell tumors. These crystals are eosinophilic, rod-shaped, crystalline inclusions found in the cytoplasm of Leydig cells. Leydig cell tumors are non-germ cell, sex cord-stromal tumors of the testicles that are typically benign.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Seminoma: Does not feature Reinke crystals; characterized by uniform cells with clear cytoplasm and central nuclei, often associated with lymphocytic infiltration.

 

Option B. Yolk sac Tumor: Lacks Reinke crystals; known for Schiller-Duval bodies and a pattern resembling endodermal sinus structures.

 

Option D. Sertoli cell Tumor: Also does not contain Reinke crystals; these tumors may show tubular or trabecular growth patterns and are often clinically silent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Reinke crystals are pathognomonic of Leydig cell tumors of the testis and are useful in differentiating these from other testicular neoplasms.

questions.text: Curtain falling sign is indicative of: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Retinal detachment

 

The curtain falling sign is a classic symptom of retinal detachment (RD), specifically rhegmatogenous retinal detachment. In this condition, a tear or hole develops in the retina, allowing fluid to pass behind it and separate the retina from the underlying tissue. As the detached portion of the retina falls forward, it creates the perception of a curtain or shadow moving across the visual field, hence the term "curtain falling sign".

 

 

Treatment: The treatment for retinal detachment involves three primary steps:

 

  1. Subretinal Fluid (SRF) Drainage: This step involves removing the fluid that has accumulated beneath the retina to allow for proper reattachment.
  2. Opposition of Retinal and Scleral Surfaces: This is achieved through:
    • Vitrectomy: Removing vitreous gel to facilitate retinal manipulation.
    • Scleral Buckling (Encirclage): Placing a band around the eye to indent the sclera and close the retinal tear.
  3. Closure of the Retinal Break: This is done using:
    • Laser Photocoagulation: Applying laser energy to create a scar that seals the break.
    • Cryopexy: Using intense cold to freeze and seal the tear.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Macular degeneration: This condition affects the central part of the retina (macula) and typically causes gradual vision loss or distortion in the central visual field, not a curtain-like shadow.

 

Option C. Optic atrophy: This refers to the degeneration of the optic nerve fibers and usually results in pale optic discs and decreased visual acuity, but does not cause a curtain-like visual phenomenon.

 

Option D. Acute anterior uveitis: This is inflammation of the front part of the uvea (iris and ciliary body) and typically causes pain, redness, and photophobia, but not a curtain-like visual symptom.

 

Educational Objective:

 

3 types of RD: Rhegmatogenous, Tractional and Exudative Retinal Detachment

 

1.   Rhegmatogenous Retinal Detachment:

  • Most common form, occurring when a tear or hole in the retina allows fluid to enter and accumulate under the retina, separating it from the underlying tissues.
  • Classical symptoms include visual flashes and floaters, which are due to the movement of the detached retina.
  • A "curtain falling" sign, where a section of the visual field appears to be shaded, is characteristic of this type.

 

2.  Tractional Retinal Detachment:

  • Occurs when fibrous or fibrovascular tissue, often resulting from proliferative diabetic retinopathy or other conditions, exerts traction on the retina, pulling it away from its underlying support tissue.

 

3.  Exudative Retinal Detachment:

  • Also known as serous retinal detachment, this type occurs without tears or breaks in the retina.
  • Fluid accumulates under the retina due to inflammation, injury, or vascular abnormalities causing leakage.

choices.text: Repair with great saphenous vein graft

questions.text: A 32-year-old female patient arrives at the emergency department with a history of stabbing injury to her arm. Upon examination, there is a noticeable hematoma, and the patient reports not feeling any radial or ulnar pulses in the affected arm. Imaging reveals a 3cm longitudinal tear in the brachial artery. The medical team is faced with deciding the best treatment option for the patient. Which option should they choose? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Repair with great saphenous vein graft

 

  • The preferred treatment option for a patient with an injury to the brachial artery caused by a stab injury is to repair it with a great saphenous vein graft harvested from the patient's uninjured leg.
  • Repairing vessel injuries requires a tension-free approach.
  • The great saphenous vein is the most desirable graft for interposition grafts because of its elastic properties, similar diameter to that of an extremity artery, lack of thrombogenicity, and long-term patency.
  • Other graft materials that can be used include the cephalic vein, lesser saphenous vein, and prosthetic conduits.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Primary repair with end-to-end anastomosis: Primary arterial repair with end-to-end anastomosis is only possible if the repair can be performed in a tension-free manner. If the injured area is too long, an interposition graft is required.

 

Option C. Repair with prosthetic graft: Prosthetic grafts are only preferred when the native saphenous vein has been traumatized or when there is a size mismatch. Polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) graft is commonly used as a prosthetic conduit.

 

Option D. Repair with saphenous vein patch: Saphenous vein patch is used for the closure of arteriotomy site during carotid endarterectomies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Repair with a great saphenous vein graft is an appropriate choice in cases of brachial artery injury with extensive damage and vascular compromise, allowing for the restoration of blood flow to the arm. This surgical intervention should be performed urgently to prevent further ischemic complications in the affected limb.

questions.text: The ligament that maintains anteversion of the uterus during pregnancy is: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Round ligament

 

Explanation:

 

The round ligament is responsible for maintaining the anteversion of the uterus, particularly during pregnancy. It consists of smooth muscle extensions of the uterine corpus and is the homologue of the gubernaculum testis. These ligaments arise from the lateral aspect of the corpus just below and anterior to the origin of the fallopian tubes, extend laterally to the pelvic sidewall, and enter the retroperitoneal space. They pass lateral to the inferior epigastric vessels before entering the inguinal canal through the internal inguinal ring and terminate in the subcutaneous tissue of the labia majora. During pregnancy, the round ligaments stretch to accommodate the enlarging uterus, helping to maintain its anteverted position. It maintains the angle of anteversion of 120¬∞

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cardinal ligament: Also known as the transverse cervical ligament or Mackenrodt ligaments, these provide significant support to the uterus and cervix by attaching the lateral aspect of the uterus and cervix to the pelvic walls. However, they do not maintain anteversion.

 

Option C. Uterosacral ligament: These ligaments insert broadly into the posterior pelvic walls and sacrum and form the lateral boundaries of the cul-de-sac (Pouch of Douglas). They play a role in supporting the uterus but do not contribute to maintaining anteversion.

 

Option D. Pubocervical ligament: This ligament forms part of the supportive structure for the uterus and vagina, attaching them to the pubic bone. It provides anterior support but does not maintain the anteversion of the uterus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The round ligament is primarily responsible for maintaining the anteversion of the uterus, especially during pregnancy.

questions.text: A patient presents with fever, cough, weight loss, histology of the pathology is as shown below. What is the most likely cytokine involved? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Interferon gamma

 

  • IFN-γ is crucial in the immune response against intracellular pathogens, including the activation of macrophages and the formation of granulomas, as seen in tuberculosis and other granulomatous diseases. It is produced primarily by T-helper cells (Th1) and is critical for orchestrating the cellular immune response that results in the granuloma formation evident in the provided histology.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Complement 5a protein: Involved in the inflammatory process, enhancing the immune response by attracting immune cells to sites of infection, but not directly involved in granuloma formation.

 

Option C. Histamine: A mediator in allergic reactions, involved in vasodilation and increased vascular permeability, not typically associated with chronic inflammatory or granulomatous responses.

 

Option D. Prostaglandin: These are lipid compounds that mediate inflammation. Like histamine, they are more often associated with immediate inflammatory responses and pain, rather than chronic inflammation or granuloma formation.

 

Educational objective:

 

Interferon gamma is key in managing intracellular infections and is responsible for the activation of macrophages and other immune cells that culminate in granuloma formation, a central feature in controlling persistent pathogens such as those seen in tuberculosis.

questions.text: A patient comes to the emergency room with a history of multiple episodes of vomiting. After being administered an intravenous drug for treatment, he develops abnormal movements. Which of the following medications can be used to manage his abnormal movements? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Benzhexol

 

Benzhexol (also known as trihexyphenidyl) is an anticholinergic agent often used to treat extrapyramidal symptoms, which include abnormal involuntary movements. These symptoms can occur as a side effect of D2 blockers like antipsychotics and some antiemetics like metoclopramide that may have been used to treat the vomiting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyoscine: This is an antispasmodic and anticholinergic drug mainly used for motion sickness and gastrointestinal spasms. It is not specifically used for treating abnormal movements such as extrapyramidal symptoms.

 

Option B. Cyproheptadine: This is an antihistamine and anticholinergic medication used mainly for allergic reactions. It is not primarily indicated for the treatment of abnormal movements.

 

Option C. Levodopa: This medication is primarily used for treating Parkinson's disease and is not indicated for the treatment of drug-induced abnormal movements unless those symptoms are related to Parkinson’s disease.

 

Therefore, in this patient who developed abnormal movements possibly due to a drug side effect, Benzhexol would be the appropriate medication for managing his symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Benzhexol (trihexyphenidyl) is the drug of choice for managing extrapyramidal symptoms, which include abnormal movements induced by medications such as D2 receptor blockers.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male patient underwent hernia surgery and complained of a loss of sensations over the root of his penis during his postoperative recovery. The patient reported no prior history of genital trauma or surgery. Which of the following nerves would you suspect to be the cause of the patient's loss of sensation? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ilioinguinal nerve

 

The ilioinguinal nerve is the most likely nerve to be implicated in this scenario. It provides sensation to the skin over the root of the penis and adjacent part of the scrotum, and can be injured during inguinal hernia repair surgery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The Iliohypogastric nerve: The Iliohypogastric nerve carries sensory supply from the suprapubic area. Injury to this nerve rarely causes sensory disturbances in the right iliac fossa due to the rich nerve supply from other sources. However, severing this nerve above the anterior superior iliac spine can lead to weakened posterior wall of the inguinal canal, resulting in a direct inguinal hernia. Injury to this nerve can also occur following appendicectomy.

 

Option C. The genitofemoral nerve: The genitofemoral nerve has a genital branch that provides sensation to the scrotum in males and mons pubis and labia majora in females. Injury to the genital branch can cause loss of sensation in these areas.

 

The femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve causes hypoesthesia over the anterior thigh below the inguinal ligament, but this is not relevant to the patient's symptoms.

 

Option D. The medial cutaneous nerve of the thigh: The medial cutaneous nerve of the thigh a sensory branch of the femoral nerve that supplies sensation to the anterior-medial aspect of the thigh and knee. Injury to this nerve can lead to loss of sensation in these areas, but is not related to the patient's loss of sensation in the root of the penis.

choices.text: Increased production of heat by liver

questions.text: Which physiological response is most likely to occur in a person exposed to high temperature while exercising vigorously to maintain internal body temperature? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sweating and vasodilation in skin

 

When a person exercises vigorously, especially in high temperatures, the body needs to maintain its internal temperature within a safe range. During exercise, the sympathetic nervous system is activated, leading to muscle contractions and relaxations. This process generates heat as a byproduct. To prevent overheating, the body employs two key mechanisms: sweating and vasodilation.

 

  • Sweating: Sweat glands produce sweat, which is released onto the skin surface. As the sweat evaporates, it helps cool the body down.
  • Vasodilation: Blood vessels in the skin widen (dilate), increasing blood flow to the skin. This allows more heat to be transferred from the body core to the skin, where it can be dissipated into the environment.

 

These processes help in losing excess heat and maintaining a stable internal body temperature during vigorous exercise.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Shivering and vasoconstriction in skin: These responses occur in cold environments to conserve heat. Shivering generates heat through muscle activity, and vasoconstriction reduces blood flow to the skin to minimize heat loss. These mechanisms are not activated in high temperatures.

 

Option C. Increased production of heat by liver: Although the liver does produce some heat, the question specifically asks for the physiological responses to high temperature and exercise. The primary responses are mechanisms to lose heat, not produce more.

 

Option D. Decreased heart rate: During vigorous exercise, the heart rate typically increases, not decreases, to supply muscles with more oxygen and nutrients. This response is part of the body's overall effort to support increased physical activity and manage heat stress.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During vigorous exercise in high temperatures, the body primarily responds by increasing sweating and vasodilation to dissipate heat and maintain a stable internal body temperature

questions.text: What type of deposition is typically observed in patients with dialysis-related amyloidosis? (FMGE July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Beta 2 microglobulin

 

Explanation:

 

Dialysis-related amyloidosis (DRA) occurs in patients who have been on long-term hemodialysis.

 

The primary protein responsible for amyloid deposits in DRA is beta 2 microglobulin. This protein tends to accumulate in patients undergoing chronic hemodialysis because it is not efficiently removed by dialysis filters.

 

The deposition of beta 2 microglobulin can lead to various musculoskeletal complications, including:

 

  • Arthritis: Particularly common in the shoulder joint, referred to as "shoulder arthropathy."
  • Tenosynovitis: Inflammation of the tendon sheath.
  • Carpal tunnel syndrome: Compression of the median nerve in the wrist, leading to pain, numbness, and weakness in the hand.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amyloid beta: This type of amyloid is primarily associated with Alzheimer's disease and is not related to dialysis.

 

Option B. Beta 1 macroglobulin: This is not related to dialysis-related amyloidosis.

 

Option D. Transthyretin: This protein can cause amyloidosis but is associated with other forms, such as senile systemic amyloidosis (wild-type transthyretin) and familial transthyretin amyloidosis (mutated transthyretin), which typically affect the heart and nervous system rather than causing musculoskeletal issues.

 

Educational Objectives

 

Dialysis-related amyloidosis is primarily caused by the accumulation of beta 2 microglobulin, leading to musculoskeletal complications such as arthritis, tenosynovitis, and carpal tunnel syndrome.
